title: Horseshoe Basin Wilderness Retreat
tagline: A remote alpine journey to the edge of the American–Canadian border.
summary: A deep wilderness retreat into one of the most remote and beautiful alpine basins in Washington State.
highlights: Backpack to the edge of the American–Canadian border
Explore vast open alpine basins and surrounding ridgelines
Views of snow-capped Canadian peaks and warm summer valleys
Hike along mountain spines with sweeping views
Experience some of the darkest night skies in Washington
Prayer, dhikr, and spiritual reflection in nature

stargazing.title: Night Under the Stars
stargazing.description: Far from any light pollution, Horseshoe Basin offers extraordinary dark skies. With a new moon during our trip window, we expect incredible views of the Milky Way and summer constellations. An optional late-night experience invites participants to wake around 1:30 AM for stargazing, followed by Qiyam al-Layl, a short spiritual reminder, and witnessing the sky brighten as Fajr enters.

dailyRhythm: Day: Hiking, exploration, learning, and rest
Evening: Camp, Maghrib, dhikr, group discussions
Night: Optional stargazing and Qiyam al-Layl

outdoorLeads.name: Yassine El Yacoubi
outdoorLeads.bio: Founder of Sakina Wilderness, WFR (Wilderness First Responder) certified outdoor leader, and science educator. Trained under NOLS-certified wilderness instructors, Yassine is passionate about backpacking, exploration, and helping people reconnect with nature as an amanah — a trust to protect and preserve the land through stewardship and respect.

outdoorLeads.name: Mubasheer
outdoorLeads.bio: Assistant outdoor leader supporting navigation, group management, and camp life throughout the journey. Bio to be updated.

whoItsFor: Adults 18+ seeking a spiritually grounded wilderness experience
Beginner-friendly with good fitness and willingness to challenge oneself
Those new to backpacking who want guidance and support
Experienced hikers seeking deeper reflection and purpose in nature
Participants open to group rhythm, prayer, and shared reflection
safety: Wilderness First Responder (WFR) certified trip lead
Small group travel with experienced leaders
Conservative pacing and risk-aware decision making
Emphasis on preparation, communication, and group care
